section.title: common directories
section.para: Below we will discuss the most common directories in alphabetical order.

section.title: /bin binaries
section.para: The /bin/bin directory contains binaries for use by all users. According to the FHS /bin should contain /bin/cat and /bin/date (and many more). You will find a bin subdirectory in many other directories. Binaries are sometimes called executablesexecutables. In the screenshot below you see common Unix/Linux commands like cat, cp, cpio, date, dd, echo, grep and so on. A lot of these will be covered in this book.
section.screen: paul@laika:~$ ls /bin archdetect egrep mt setupcon autopartition false mt-gnu sh bash fgconsole mv sh.distrib bunzip2 fgrep nano sleep bzcat fuser nc stralign bzcmp fusermount nc.traditional stty bzdiff get_mountoptions netcat su bzegrep grep netstat sync bzexe gunzip ntfs-3g sysfs bzfgrep gzexe ntfs-3g.probe tailf bzgrep gzip parted_devices tar bzip2 hostname parted_server tempfile bzip2recover hw-detect partman touch bzless ip partman-commit true bzmore kbd_mode perform_recipe ulockmgr cat kill pidof umount ...

section.title: /boot static files to boot the system
section.para: The /boot/boot directory contains all files needed to boot the computer. These files don't change very often. On Linux systems you typically find the /boot/grub/boot/grub directory here. This /boot/grub contains /boot/grub/menu.lst/boot/grub/menu.lst (the grub configuration file is often linked to /boot/grub/grub.conf/boot/grub/grub.conf), which defines the boot menu that is being displayed before the kernel starts.

section.title: /dev device files
section.para: Device files in /dev/dev appear to be ordinary files, but are not located on the hard disk. The /dev directory is populated with files when the kernel is recognizing hardware.

section.title: common physical devices
section.para: Common hardware such as hard disk devices are represented by device files in /dev. Below a screenshot of SATA device files on a laptop and then IDE attached drives on a desktop. (The detailed meaning of these devices will be discussed later.)
section.screen:
# # SATA or SCSI # paul@laika:~$ ls /dev/sd* /dev/sda /dev/sda1 /dev/sda2 /dev/sda3 /dev/sdb /dev/sdb1 /dev/sdb2
# # IDE or ATAPI # paul@barry:~$ ls /dev/hd* /dev/hda /dev/hda1 /dev/hda2 /dev/hdb /dev/hdb1 /dev/hdb2 /dev/hdc
section.para: Besides representing physical hardware, some device files are special. These special devices can be very useful.

section.title: /dev/tty and /dev/pts
section.para: For example /dev/tty1/dev/tty1 represents a terminal or console attached to the system. (Don't break your head on the exact terminology of 'terminal' or 'console', what we mean here is a command line interface.) When typing commands in a terminal that is part of a graphical interface like Gnome or KDE, then your terminal will be represented as /dev/pts/1/dev/pts/1 (1 can be another number).

section.title: /dev/null
section.para: On Linux you will find special devices like /dev/null/dev/null which can be considered a black hole, it has unlimited storage, but nothing can be retrieved from it. Technically speaking, anything given to /dev/null will be discarded. /dev/null can be useful to discard unwanted output from commands. /dev/null is not a good location to store all your backups ;-).

section.title: /etc configuration files
section.para: All of the machine-specific configuration files should be located in /etc/etc. Many times the name of a configuration files is the same as the application or daemon or protocol with .conf added as an extension. But there is much more to be found in /etc.

section.title: /etc/X11/
section.para: The graphical display (aka X Window SystemX Window System or just XX) is driven by software from the X.org foundation. The configuration file for your graphical display is /etc/X11/xorg.conf/etc/X11/xorg.conf.

section.title: /etc/skel/
section.para: The skeletonskeleton directory /etc/skel/etc/skel is copied to the home directory of a newly created user. It usually contains hidden files like a .bashrc script.

section.title: /etc/sysconfig/
section.para: This directory, which is not mentioned in the FHS, contains a lot of Red Hat Enterprise Linux configuration files. We will discuss some of them in greater detail. The screenshot below is the /etc/sysconfig/etc/sysconfig from RHELv4u4 with everything installed.
section.screen: paul@RHELv4u4:~$ ls /etc/sysconfig/ apmd firstboot irda network saslauthd apm-scripts grub irqbalance networking selinux authconfig hidd keyboard ntpd spamassassin autofs httpd kudzu openib.conf squid bluetooth hwconf lm_sensors pand syslog clock i18n mouse pcmcia sys-config-sec console init mouse.B pgsql sys-config-users crond installinfo named prelink sys-logviewer desktop ipmi netdump rawdevices tux diskdump iptables netdump_id_dsa rhn vncservers dund iptables-cfg netdump_id_dsa.p samba xinetd paul@RHELv4u4:~$
section.para: The file /etc/sysconfig/firstboot/etc/sysconfig/firstboot tells the Red Hat Setup Agent to not run at boot time. If you want to run the Red Hat Setup Agent at the next reboot, then simply remove this file, and run chkconfig --level 5 firstboot onchkconfig. The Red Hat Setup Agent allows you to install the latest updates, create a user account, join the Red Hat Network and more. It will then create the /etc/sysconfig/firstboot file again.
The file /etc/sysconfig/harddisks/etc/sysconfig/harddisks contains some parameters to tune the hard disks. The file explains itself.
You can see hardware detected by kudzukudzu in /etc/sysconfig/hwconf/etc/sysconfig/hwconf. Kudzu is software from Red Hat for automatic discovery and configuration of hardware.

The keyboard type and table are set in the /etc/sysconfig/keyboard/etc/sysconfig/keyboard file. For more console keyboard information, check the manual pages of keymaps(5)keymaps(5), dumpkeys(1)dumpkeys(1), loadkeys(1)loadkeys(1) and the directory /lib/kbd/keymaps//lib/kbd/keymaps/.
We will discuss the networking files in this directory in the networking chapter.

section.title: /home sweet home
section.para: You will find a lot of locations with an extensive hierarchy of personal or project data under /home/home. It is common practice (but not mandatory) to name the users home directory after their username in the format /home/$USERNAME. Like in this example:
section.screen: paul@pasha:~$ ls /home geert guillaume maria paul tom
section.para: Besides giving every user (or every project or group) a location to store personal files, the home directory of a user also serves as a location to store the user profile. A typical Unix user profile contains a bunch of hidden files (files who's filename starts with a dot). The hidden files of the Unix user profile contain settings specific for that user.

section.title: /initrd
section.para: This empty directory is used as a mount point by Red Hat Enterprise Linux during boot time. Removing it causes a kernel panic during the next boot.

section.title: /lib shared libraries
section.para: Binaries, like those found in /bin, often use shared libraries located in /lib/lib. Below a partial screenshot of the contents of /lib.

section.title: /lib/modules
section.para: Typically, the kernel loads kernel modules from /lib/modules/$kernel-version/lib/modules. This directory is discussed in detail in the Linux kernel chapter.

section.title: /lib32 and /lib64
section.para: We are now in a transition between 32-bit and 64-bit systems. So you might encounter directories named /lib32/lib32 and /lib64/lib64, to clarify the register size used at compilation time of the libraries. My current 64-bit laptop has some older 32-bit binaries and libraries for compatibility with legacy applications. The screenshot uses the filefile(1) utility to point out the difference.
section.screen: paul@laika:~$ file /lib32/libc-2.5.so /lib32/libc-2.5.so: ELF 32-bit LSB shared object, Intel 80386, \ version 1 (SYSV), for GNU/Linux 2.6.0, stripped paul@laika:~$ file /lib64/libcap.so.1.10 /lib64/libcap.so.1.10: ELF 64-bit LSB shared object, AMD x86-64, \ version 1 (SYSV), stripped
section.para: The ELF Executable and Linkable FormatELF is used in almost every Unix-like operating system since System V.

section.title: /media for removable media
section.para: The /media/media directory serves as a mount point for removable media, meaning devices such as CD-ROM's, digital cameras and various usb-attached devices. Since /media is rather new in the Unix world, you could very well encounter systems running without this directory. Solaris 9 does not have it, Solaris 10 does. Most Linux distributions today mount all removable media in /media.

section.title: /mnt standard mount point
section.para: Unix and Linux administrators used to mount all kind of stuff under /mnt/something/. According to the FHS, /mnt/mnt should only be used to temporarily mount something. But you will most likely witness a lot of systems with more than one directory underneath /mnt used as a mount point for various local and remote filesystems.

section.title: /opt optional software
section.para: Most of my systems today have an empty /opt/opt directory. It is considered outdated, but you might find some systems with add-on software installed in /opt. If that is the case, the package should install all its files in the typical bin, lib, etc subdirectories in /opt/$packagename/. If for example the package is called wp, then it installs in /opt/wp, putting binaries in /opt/wp/bin and manpages in /opt/wp/man. Most of the default software which comes along with the distribution, will not be installed in /opt.

section.title: /proc conversation with the kernel
section.para: /proc/proc is another special directory, appearing to be ordinary files, but not taking up disk space. It is actually a view on the kernel, or better on what the kernel sees, and a means to talk to the kernel directly. /proc is a proc filesystem.
section.screen: paul@RHELv4u4:~$ mount -t proc none on /proc type proc (rw)
section.para: When listing the /proc directory, you will see a lot of numbers (on any Unix), and some interesting files (on Linux)
Let's investigate the file properties inside /proc. Looking at the date and time will display the current date and time, meaning the files are constantly updated (A view on the kernel).
section.screen: paul@RHELv4u4:~$ date Mon Jan 29 18:06:32 EST 2007 paul@RHELv4u4:~$ ls -al /proc/cpuinfo -r--r--r-- 1 root root 0 Jan 29 18:06 /proc/cpuinfo paul@RHELv4u4:~$ paul@RHELv4u4:~$ ...time passes... paul@RHELv4u4:~$ paul@RHELv4u4:~$ date Mon Jan 29 18:10:00 EST 2007 paul@RHELv4u4:~$ ls -al /proc/cpuinfo -r--r--r-- 1 root root 0 Jan 29 18:10 /proc/cpuinfo
section.para: Most files in /proc are 0 bytes, yet they contain data, sometimes a lot of data. You can see this by executing cat on files like /proc/cpuinfo/proc/cpuinfo, which contains information on the CPU.
section.screen: paul@RHELv4u4:~$ file /proc/cpuinfo /proc/cpuinfo: empty paul@RHELv4u4:~$ cat /proc/cpuinfo processor : 0 vendor_id : AuthenticAMD cpu family : 15 model : 43 model name : AMD Athlon(tm) 64 X2 Dual Core Processor 4600+ stepping : 1 cpu MHz : 2398.628 cache size : 512 KB fdiv_bug : no hlt_bug : no f00f_bug : no coma_bug : no fpu : yes fpu_exception : yes cpuid level : 1 wp : yes flags : fpu vme de pse tsc msr pae mce cx8 apic mtrr pge... bogomips : 4803.54

para.emphasis: Just for fun, here is /proc/cpuinfo on a Sun Sunblade 1000...

section.screen: paul@pasha:~$ cat /proc/cpuinfo cpu : TI UltraSparc III (Cheetah) fpu : UltraSparc III integrated FPU promlib : Version 3 Revision 2 prom : 4.2.2 type : sun4u ncpus probed : 2 ncpus active : 2 Cpu0Bogo : 498.68 Cpu0ClkTck : 000000002cb41780 Cpu1Bogo : 498.68 Cpu1ClkTck : 000000002cb41780 MMU Type : Cheetah State: CPU0: online CPU1: online

[root@ps3 tmp]# uname -a Linux ps3 2.6.20-rc5 #58 SMP Thu Jan 18 13:35:01 CET 2007 ppc64 ppc64 ppc64 GNU/Linux [root@ps3 tmp]# cat /proc/cpuinfo processor : 0 cpu : Cell Broadband Engine, altivec supported clock : 3192.000000MHz revision : 5.1 (pvr 0070 0501)
processor : 1 cpu : Cell Broadband Engine, altivec supported clock : 3192.000000MHz revision : 5.1 (pvr 0070 0501)
timebase : 79800000 platform : PS3 machine : PS3
section.para: Most of the files in /proc are read only, some require root privileges. But some files are writable, a lot of files in /proc/sys/proc/sys are writable. Let's discuss some of the files in /proc.

section.title: /proc/filesystems
section.para: The /proc/filesystems/proc/filesystems file displays a list of supported file systems. When you mount a file system without explicitly defining one, then mount will first try to probe /etc/filesystems/etc/filesystems and then probe /proc/filesystems for all the filesystems in there without the nodevnodev label. If /etc/filesystems ends with a line containing nothing but a *, then both files are probed.
section.screen: paul@RHELv4u4:~$ cat /proc/filesystems nodev sysfs nodev rootfs nodev bdev nodev proc nodev sockfs nodev binfmt_misc nodev usbfs nodev usbdevfs nodev futexfs nodev tmpfs nodev pipefs nodev eventpollfs nodev devpts ext2 nodev ramfs nodev hugetlbfs iso9660 nodev relayfs nodev mqueue nodev selinuxfs ext3 nodev rpc_pipefs nodev vmware-hgfs nodev autofs paul@RHELv4u4:~$

section.para: On the x86 architecture, /proc/interrupts/proc/interrupts displays the interrupts.

section.title: /proc/kcore
section.para: The physical memory is represented in /proc/kcore/proc/kcore. Do not try to cat this file, instead use a debugger. The size of /proc/kcore is the same as your physical memory, plus four bytes.

section.title: /proc/swaps
section.para: You can find information about swap partition(s)swap partition(s) in /proc/swaps/proc/swaps.
section.screen: paul@RHELv4u4:~$ cat /proc/swaps Filename Type Size Used Priority /dev/mapper/VolGroup00-LogVol01 partition 1048568 0 -1 paul@RHELv4u4:~$

section.title: /root the superuser's home
section.para: On many systems, /root/root is the default location for the root user's personal data and profile. If it does not exist by default, then some administrators create it.

section.title: /sbin system binaries
section.para: Similar to /bin, but mainly for booting and for tools to configure the system. A lot of the system binaries will require root privileges for certain tasks. You will also find a /sbin/sbin subdirectory in other directories.

section.title: /srv served by your system
section.para: You may find /srv/srv to be empty on many systems, but not for long. The FHS suggests locating cvs, rsync, ftp and www data to this location. The FHS also approves administrative naming in /srv, like /srv/project55/ftp and /srv/sales/www. Red Hat plans to move some data that is currently located in /var to /srv.

section.title: /sys Linux 2.6 hot plugging
section.para: The /sys/sys directory is created for the Linux 2.6 kernel. Since 2.6, Linux uses sysfssysfs to support usbusb and IEEE 1394IEEE 1394 (aka FireWireFireWire) hot plug devices. See the manual pages of udev(8) (the successor of devfsdevfs) and hotplug(8) for more info (Or visit http://linux-hotplug.sourceforge.net/ ).

section.title: /tmp for temporary files
section.para: When applications (or Users) need to store temporary data, they should use /tmp/tmp. /tmp might take up disk space, then again, it might also not (as in being mounted inside RAM memory). In any case, files in /tmp can be cleared by the operating system. Never use /tmp to store data that you want to archive.

section.title: /usr Unix system resources
section.para: Although /usr/usr is pronounced like user, never forget that it stands for Unix System Resources. The /usr hierarchy should contain sharable, read only data. Some people even choose to mount /usr as read only. This can be done from its own partition, or from a read only NFS share.

section.title: /var variable data
section.para: Data that is unpredictable in size, such as log files (/var/log/var/log), print spool directories (/var/spool/var/spool) and various caches (/var/cache/var/cache) should be located in /var/var. But /var is much more than that, it contains Process ID files in /var/run/var/run and temporary files that survive a reboot in /var/tmp/var/tmp. There will be more examples of /var usage further in this book.

section.title: /var/lib/rpm
section.para: Red Hat Enterprise Linux keeps files pertaining to RPMRPM in /var/lib/rpm//var/lib/rpm.

section.title: /var/spool/up2date
section.para: The Red Hat Update AgentRed Hat Update Agent uses files in /var/spool/up2date/var/spool/up2date. This location is also used when files are downloaded from the Red Hat NetworkRed Hat Network.

section.title: Practice: file system tree
section.para: 1. Does the file /bin/cat exist ? What about /bin/dd and /bin/echo. What is the type of these files ?
2. What is the size of the Linux kernel file(s) (vmlinu*) in /boot ?
3. Create a directory ~/test. Then issue the following commands:
dd will copy one times (count=1) a block of size 100 bytes (bs=100) from the file /dev/zero to ~/test/zeroes.txt. Can you describe the functionality of /dev/zero ?
4. Now issue the following command:
section.screen: dd if=/dev/random of=random.txt count=1 bs=100 ; od random.txt
section.para: dd will copy one times (count=1) a block of size 100 bytes (bs=100) from the file /dev/random to ~/test/random.txt. Can you describe the functionality of /dev/random ?
5. Issue the following two commands, and look at the first character of each output line.
The first ls will show block(b) devices, the second ls shows character(c) devices. Can you tell the difference between block and character devices ?
6. Use cat to display /etc/hosts and /etc/resolv.conf. What is your idea about the purpose of these files ?
7. Are there any files in /etc/skel/ ? Check also for hidden files.
8. Display /proc/cpuinfo. On what architecture is your Linux running ?
9. Display /proc/interrupts. What is the size of this file ? Where is this file stored ?
10. Can you enter the /root directory ? Are there (hidden) files ?
11. Are ifconfig, fdisk, parted, shutdown and grub-install present in /sbin ? Why are these binaries in /sbin and not in /bin ?
12. Is /var/log a file or a directory ? What about /var/spool ?
13. Open two command prompts (Ctrl-Shift-T in gnome-terminal) or terminals (Ctrl-Alt-F1, Ctrl-Alt-F2, ...) and issue the who am i in both. Then try to echo a word from one terminal to the other.
14. Read the man page of random and explain the difference between /dev/random and /dev/urandom/dev/urandom.

section.title: Solutions: file system tree
section.para: 1. Does the file /bin/cat exist ? What about /bin/dd and /bin/echo. What is the type of these files ?
2. What is the size of the Linux kernel file(s) (vmlinu*) in /boot ?
3. Create a directory ~/test. Then issue the following commands:
dd will copy one times (count=1) a block of size 100 bytes (bs=100) from the file /dev/zero to ~/test/zeroes.txt. Can you describe the functionality of /dev/zero ?
/dev/zero/dev/zero is a Linux special device. It can be considered a source of zeroes. You cannot send something to /dev/zero, but you can read zeroes from it.
4. Now issue the following command:
section.screen: dd if=/dev/random of=random.txt count=1 bs=100 ; od random.txt
section.para: dd will copy one times (count=1) a block of size 100 bytes (bs=100) from the file /dev/random to ~/test/random.txt. Can you describe the functionality of /dev/random ?
/dev/random/dev/random acts as a random number generatorrandom number generator on your Linux machine.
5. Issue the following two commands, and look at the first character of each output line.
The first ls will show block(b) devices, the second ls shows character(c) devices. Can you tell the difference between block and character devices ?

Block devices are always written to (or read from) in blocks. For hard disks, blocks of 512 bytes are common. Character devices act as a stream of characters (or bytes). Mouse and keyboard are typical character devices.
6. Use cat to display /etc/hosts and /etc/resolv.conf. What is your idea about the purpose of these files ?
section.screen: /etc/hosts/etc/hosts contains hostnames with their ip address
/etc/resolv.conf/etc/resolv.conf should contain the ip address of a DNS name server.
section.para: 7. Are there any files in /etc/skel/ ? Check also for hidden files.
section.screen: Issue "ls -al /etc/skel/". Yes, there should be hidden files there.
section.para: 8. Display /proc/cpuinfo. On what architecture is your Linux running ?
section.screen: The file should contain at least one line with Intel or other cpu.
section.para: 9. Display /proc/interrupts. What is the size of this file ? Where is this file stored ?

The size is zero, yet the file contains data. It is not stored anywhere because /proc is a virtual file system that allows you to talk with the kernel. (If you answered "stored in RAM-memory, that is also correct...).
10. Can you enter the /root directory ? Are there (hidden) files ?
section.screen: Try "cd /root". Yes there are (hidden) files there.
section.para: 11. Are ifconfig, fdisk, parted, shutdown and grub-install present in /sbin ? Why are these binaries in /sbin and not in /bin ?
section.screen: Because those files are only meant for system administrators.
section.para: 12. Is /var/log a file or a directory ? What about /var/spool ?
13. Open two command prompts (Ctrl-Shift-T in gnome-terminal) or terminals (Ctrl-Alt-F1, Ctrl-Alt-F2, ...) and issue the who am i in both. Then try to echo a word from one terminal to the other.
14. Read the man page of random and explain the difference between /dev/random and /dev/urandom/dev/urandom.
